The Wimpy Kid (Jeff Kinney) Meets the National Ambassador (Gene Yang)
videos.description:
At An Unlikely Story bookstore in Plainville, MA, Gene sits down for a lively conversation with Wimpy Kid author (and bookstore owner) Jeff Kinney.

As a kid, Kinney was a prankster and a devoted reader of his sister's Judy Blume books. He later discovered fantasy (The Hobbitt, The Lord of the Rings, and the Xanth series), comics (The Far Side, Calvin and Hobbes), and the genius of Carl Barks (Donald Duck comics).

Kinney talks about how his early dream of being a newspaper comic strip writer led to the creation of Greg Heffley and his middle school world. Listen in as Kinney shares some sage advice with young people who want to be cartoonists — and why cartooning is the art of simplification.

videos.title: Meet Superstar Web Cartoonist Ngozi Ukazu
videos.description:
At the 2017 Emerald City Comic-Con in Seattle, Gene meets up with Ngozi Ukazu, creator of the popular web comic, Check Please! — the quirky story of a pie-baking college hockey player.

Ngozi has been putting pictures and words together since elementary school. She was the comics editor in high school and kept on drawing in college. She graduated from Yale University in 2013 with a degree in Computing and The Arts, and received a masters in Sequential Art in 2015 from the Savannah College of Art and Design.

In this podcast, Gene and Ngozi bond over their shared love of animated TV shows (Justice League, The Simpsons) and sitcoms from the 90s

videos.title: Look What You've Done! Stories of Hope and Resilience
videos.description:
Dr. Robert Brooks offers practical strategies for helping children develop the confidence and resilience they will need to succeed.

“Look what you’ve done!” Whether they’ve failed a spelling test or dropped an easy pop fly, kids with learning disabilities hear those words far too often. It’s no wonder they often give up hope. And it’s no wonder we sometimes overlook what Dr. Brooks calls the “everyday courage” of our children. Dr. Brooks says we need to find each child’s “islands of competence” and then build on those strengths. He offers practical strategies for helping children develop the confidence and resilience they will need to succeed.

Download the Parents' Viewing Guide here: http://owl.li/kKpW30jalBV

Download the Teachers' Viewing Guide here: http://owl.li/y17530jalEJ

videos.description:

Rick Lavoie aborda los problemas sociales que enfrentan estos niños y ofrece algunas soluciones prácticas para los padres.

videos.description: We have a lot of inquiries from parents who really would like us to do an MRI on their child because they feel their child is a struggling reader and the school isn’t recognizing it. And they’re hoping that the brain scan will show it. But that’s now how we use the brain scans. We really do look at data for a group. We do look at individual variation, but we wouldn’t be able to go in and look at one scan and say, “This is a child who has dyslexia.”

What is the dyslexia paradox?
videos.description: The dyslexia paradox is the discrepancy between when we currently diagnose dyslexia and when research has shown the most optimal window for early reading intervention is. So currently we are diagnosing kids after repeated failure — so we also call it the "wait to fail paradox" or "wait to fail approach" — which is usually at the end of second grade at the earliest, maybe beginning of third grade.

videos.title: What are the effects of delaying identification of and intervention for dyslexia?
videos.description: Dyslexia goes along with a lot of social and psychological and clinical implications such as reduced self-esteem, depression, higher rates of anxiety, reading motivation goes down, etc. So the longer we let the kids fail and not give them the resources they need, the more likely they are to have reduced reading motivation.

videos.title: What does the research say about screening young children for dyslexia?
videos.description: Research has shown that interventions are most effective in kindergarten and first grade. It's important to say that we're not diagnosing or identifying children with dyslexia at that age. We are identifying children who are at a heightened risk to develop dyslexia.

videos.title: How can early detection of dyslexia be improved?
videos.description: A lot of the screeners out there are not screening all of the components important for learning to read — meaning things like phonological awareness, which is the ability to manipulate the sounds of language, letter sound, letter name knowledge, etc. You also want to screen for vocabulary as well as oral listening comprehension.

videos.title: Blending Sounds in Syllables with Autumn, Kindergartner
videos.description:
This episode focuses on phonological awareness. Reading expert Linda Farrell helps kindergartener Autumn learn to blend two parts of a syllable (onset and rime). Watch how Ms. Farrell gives Autumn explicit practice with onset and rime — a core phonological awareness skill that helps kids recognize and blend sound chunks within syllables. 

This is an essential step toward developing phonemic awareness. Phonemic awareness, a vital pre-reading skill, is being able to blend, segment, and manipulate the sounds in words.

This video is part of the reading Rockets special series, Looking at Reading Interventions. Watch additional episodes and download the accompanying Professional Development Guides here: https://www.readingrockets.org/interventions

videos.title: Letter Names with Reese, Kindergartener
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell works with Reese to master the name of every letter. She helps Reese sing the alphabet song clearly and with no mistakes. She teaches him to look carefully at letters as he names them. Ms. Farrell also helps Reese identify every letter of the alphabet accurately, including differentiating between letters that look similar (in Reese’s case, ‘y’ and ‘v’). Learning the name of every letter is a critical pre-reading skill.

This video is part of the reading Rockets special series, Looking at Reading Interventions. Watch additional episodes and download the accompanying Professional Development Guides here: https://www.readingrockets.org/interventions

Visit the Reading Rockets channel here: https://www.youtube.com/user/wetalearningmedia

videos.title: Mastering Short Vowels and Reading Whole Words with Calista, First Grader
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell works with Calista, an early stage reader, on short vowel sounds, blending and manipulating sounds, reading whole words, and fluency. Ms. Farrell starts by making sure Calista has a strong foundation in short vowel sounds by teaching her hand motions to remember those sounds more easily.

After Calista demonstrates she knows short vowel sounds, Ms. Farrell teaches her to change one sound in a spoken word using manipulatives. Finally, Ms. Farrell helps Calista move from sound-by-sound reading to whole word reading.

videos.title: Reading Multisyllable Words with Xavier, Third Grader
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell shows Xavier how to read and spell unfamiliar multisyllable words with one vowel letter in each syllable. First she makes sure that Xavier has three prerequisite skills: being able to read one-syllable nonsense words, knowing how to count syllables in spoken words, and naming the vowel letters. Xavier learns that every syllable has a vowel, and that he can count the vowel letters to break a long word into syllables to make it easy to read. To figure out how many syllables are in a word, Ms. Farrell teaches Xavier to ask two questions: How many vowels are in the word? Are the vowels together or apart?

This video is part of the reading Rockets special series, Looking at Reading Interventions. Watch additional episodes and download the accompanying Professional Development Guides here: https://www.readingrockets.org/interventions

videos.title: Learning ‘b’ and ‘d’ and Reading Short Vowel Words with Aiko, Second Grader
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell works with Aiko on a common letter reversal — confusing the letters ‘b’ and ‘d’. Ms. Farrell coaches Aiko to look at the letters during b/d practice and to look at the words while she works with Aiko to read short vowel words accurately.

videos.title: Mastering ‘Silent e’ and Becoming More Fluent with Michael, Third Grader
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell helps Michael master the ‘silent e’ pattern to help him become a more accurate and ultimately more fluid reader. She begins with making sure that Michael can distinguish between short and long vowel sounds in spoken words, then teaches him a multi-sensory way to recognize the short vowel and ‘silent e’ long vowel patterns in written words. Ms. Farrell emphasizes the need to practice each skill to the point of mastery.

This video is part of the reading Rockets special series, Looking at Reading Interventions. Watch additional episodes and download the accompanying Professional Development Guides here: https://www.readingrockets.org/interventions

Visit the Reading Rockets channel here: https://www.youtube.com/user/wetalearningmedia

videos.title: Reading SOS: Sounding out the same words again and again
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell sees this often with striving readers, and she shares a simple tip: encourage your child to silently "think" the sounds as he reads the word. Linda also emphasizes how important it is for kids to keep their eyes on the words as they read.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: How do I explain "ea"?
videos.description:
A parent asks about the best way to the "ea" vowel combination (also called a vowel team). Reading expert Linda Farrell explains that you begin with the most common pronunciation, and then teach the exceptions.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Do Bob Books help young readers?
videos.description:
A parent asks if the Bob Books — a step-by-step early reader series — help her young son with reading. He likes to read them over and over again! Reading expert Linda Farrell shares her thoughts on these early readers as well as the importance of reading aloud to build vocabulary and background knowledge.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Which letter sounds do I teach first?
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell recommends that you begin with teaching the letter names, and then focus on the letter sounds that are closest to their letter names (such as /v/). And here's a great tip for teaching the trickier letter name–letter sound combinations — use arm motions. In this video, Linda demonstrates motions for /x/ and /y/.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Getting stuck on sight words
videos.description:
Many striving readers struggle with sight words. Reading expert Linda Farrell suggests this teaching sequence: first, be sure your child knows all the letter names, then all the letter sounds — and then you can introduce a few short high-frequency words such as was. Choose words that don't have regular phonetic spelling. Words that do have phonetic spelling, such as in, did, and on can be folded into phonics lessons.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Finding a good reading program for a child with LD
videos.description:
Reading expert Linda Farrell provides guidance in understanding the three features that all good reading programs should have: (1) phonological awareness and phonemic awareness, (2) a strong phonics scope and sequence, and (3) lots of opportunities for kids to practice what they've learned in their phonics lessons.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Encouraging reading when its hard
videos.description:
A parent asks about the best way to encourage reading when a child finds it difficult. Literacy expert Kegi Wells explains different strategies to help children to become stronger and more engaged readers.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn how to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Should I be concerned if my child reads slowly?
videos.description:
A parent is concerned that her child reads accurately but very slowly. Literacy expert Kegi Wells explains that what's most important is if your child understands what she's reading. Kegi offers simple ways to check for understanding and how to model expressive reading.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: How can I help my four year old learn more words?
videos.description:
Literacy expert Sandra Wilborn shares three key ways to build your young child's vocabulary: lots of family talk, narrating your every day activities such as cooking or shopping, and reading to your child — while pointing out new words and then using them in your conversations.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: teaching my child how to read
helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Does my child, who is learning English, need special education?
videos.description:
A parent asks about her child, who reads fluently in her home language, Spanish, but is being referred for special education. Language and literacy expert Elsa Cárdenas-Hagan recommends that she ask the school if the testing is being done in English or in the home language. That's important to know, because the areas of concern may be related to learning English rather than any underlying issue. Don't be afraid to ask questions and advocate for your child!

See this question and answer in Spanish: ¿Mi hijo, que está aprendiendo inglés, necesita educación especial? (Colorín Colorado). https://www.colorincolorado.org/es/video/lectura-sos/educaci%C3%B3n-especial

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: teaching my child how to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: How do I help my child learn new words while we read aloud?
videos.description:
Reading aloud is a great way for children to learn new words. Literacy expert Sandra Wilborn suggests that parents pause during the read aloud to elaborate on a new word by giving a simple definition, connecting the word to something your child knows, and using it in a sentence. Reinforce the learning by using that new word at home in the weeks ahead.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: teaching my child how to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: Should I tell my child to look up words in the dictionary?
videos.description:
It's still okay to encourage your child to look up unfamiliar words in the dictionary (remember to do it with them!) — but that's just the first step. Literacy expert Sandra Wilborn says that vocabulary development is a process that requires lots of exposure to a word in order to really learn it. Find out about the other simple things parents can do to reinforce word learning.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: My first grader struggles to remember the alphabet in our home language of Spanish.
videos.description:
Language and literacy expert Elsa Cárdenas-Hagan says that it's important to find out early if your child is having difficulty with letters and sounds. Ask your child's teacher if she has been screened or tested in your home language, and learn the early warning signs for dyslexia. Elsa also shares easy ways to help your child practice letters and sounds at home — one way is to build on the connections between English and Spanish.

See this question and answer in Spanish: Mi hija está en primer grado y tiene dificultades para aprender las letras en nuestro idioma, español (Colorín Colorado). https://www.colorincolorado.org/es/video/lectura-sos-mi-hija-tiene-dificultades-para-aprender-las-letras

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: My child is learning English. How can we tell if she needs help with speech issues?
videos.description:
Language and literacy expert Elsa Cárdenas-Hagan suggests that you have your child screened in English and Spanish to determine if the issue is related to language or to mastering speech sounds. Next, Elsa describes the milestones for learning speech sounds, beginning at age one. By the end of first grade, your child should know all of the speech sounds, no matter what the language.

See this question and answer in Spanish: ¿Mi hijo, que está aprendiendo inglés, tiene un problema del habla? (Colorín Colorado). https://www.colorincolorado.org/es/video/lectura-sos-mi-hijo-tiene-un-problema-del-habla 

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: Should I correct my child when she reads aloud to me?
videos.description:
Literacy expert Sandra Wilborn says that if your child is reading out loud for fun, it's best to just offer a gentle, quick correction and move on. But if your child is reading aloud as part of a more structured learning time, you should offer more guidance, such as encouraging your child to slow down and sound out unfamiliar words, and to check for understanding ("Does that sentence make sense?").

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts
tags: helping my child learn to read

videos.title: Reading SOS: I am still learning English myself. How can I help my child learn to read in English?
videos.description:
One of the most important things parents can do is provide lots of language and literacy experiences at home. Language and literacy expert Elsa Cárdenas-Hagan suggests that you share family stories with your child, use descriptive vocabulary in everyday conversations, and try to read aloud for at least 20 minutes each day to model fluent reading and comprehension skills.

See this question and answer in Spanish: Aún estoy aprendiendo inglés. Entonces, ¿cómo puedo ayudar a mi hijo a aprender a leer? (Colorín Colorado). https://www.colorincolorado.org/es/video/lectura-sos-ayudar-mi-hijo-aprender-leer

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: My child wants to do all of her reading on an electronic device
videos.description:
Literacy expert Kegi Wells says that electronic readers are fine — although parents should watch out for too many bells and whistles that can distract kids from paying attention to the text. However, she recommends finding a balance between e-readers and print books. Print books help young children build print awareness, an important early literacy skill.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: What can I do when my child gets frustrated with technology?
videos.description:
Virtual learning presents many challenges for our kids learning from home. Accessing and using technology can sometimes be difficult, and feeling frustrated when things don't work is normal for kids (adults feel it, too!). Third grade teacher Chelsey Short provides practical and easy tips for helping your child successfully navigate technology at home.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: How can I help my child read more smoothly?
videos.description:
A parent says that her second grader is pretty good at reading but sounds robotic when he reads aloud. Third grade teacher Chelsey Short explains that if your child understands what they're reading, then you don't need to worry too much. Reading with appropriate expression is a skill that develops over time as your child grows in confidence with their reading. Chelsey offers simple and fun ideas for helping your child become a more expressive, fluent reader.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: Where should my third grader do online research?
videos.description:
What should you do if your child always goes to Wikipedia to do research? School tech expert Mike Carvella offers alternative online sources that are kid-friendly and trustworthy. You might also check to see what subscription services your child's school or district offers that provide free access to online encyclopedias and more.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: What are some tips to help parents coping with virtual learning?
videos.description:
Get five practical tips from school technology expert Mike Carvella on how you can help your child be more successful with virtual learning. Mike's tips include showing your child how to use "help" tools to become more independent and learning about digital citizenship together.

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: With today's technology is handwriting instruction important?
videos.description:
A parent asks if children today still need handwriting instruction since they do so much writing on computers and devices. Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that children need direct and explicit handwriting instruction in order to link letter names, the way letters look, and their sounds. These important connections help them with their reading, spelling, and writing, which is why handwriting instruction is so important in primary years.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts"
tags: helping my child learn to write

videos.title: Writing SOS: Should grammar still be taught in school?
videos.description:
A parent asks whether grammar should still be taught in school. Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that understanding how sentences work helps to improve both reading comprehension and writing, especially when we want students to express themselves through rich language. In other words, the answer is yes – grammar matters!

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: Is there value to having my child learn prefixes and suffixes?
videos.description:
A parent asks if learning prefixes and suffixes is helpful for children. Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that prefixes and suffixes are useful to learn because they help children understand meaning, build vocabulary, and learn how to spell and decode. 

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: How can I help my child organize their ideas to help them write?
videos.description:
How can a parent help his child who has a lot of a great ideas but trouble organizing them? Writing expert William Van Cleave suggests a few pre-writing steps to help children organize their ideas. First, it may help for parents to write the ideas down so that handwriting and spelling aren’t the focus, especially for young children. In addition, it may help to make a list of the ideas that can be cut up so the pieces can be moved around. With some pre-writing planning and organization in place, the ideas will flow more smoothly once the writing begins.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: How can I get my child interested in writing?
videos.description:
A parent is wondering what to do about the weekly battles she and her third grader have about writing assignments. Writing expert William Van Cleave talks about the importance of showing enthusiasm for the topic children are writing about and helping them get their ideas organized using graphic organizers and lists.  

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: How can learning to spell help my child?
videos.description:
A parent wonders why children need to learn to spell if we have spell checkers. Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that the link between spelling and literacy is important, especially when there are multiple ways to write a sound such as /k/, like in the words cat, click, and kite. He also notes that learning how to spell words automatically frees up space to concentrate on the ideas for writing, rather than just how the words are spelled.  

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: My kindergartner still says "mouses." Should I correct her?
videos.description:
A parent wonders whether to correct her kindergartner when she says “mouses.” Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that the child is showing that she understands how plural nouns work, but that she hasn’t yet learned that “mouse” doesn’t follow typical spelling patterns. He recommends pausing, saying the word the right way, asking the child to repeat it, and moving on. It will take some repetition, he notes, but will help her learn irregular words.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Writing SOS: How can I get my third grader to use better words in his speaking and writing?
videos.description:
A parent asks what he might do to help his third grader use more interesting words when he is speaking and writing. Writing expert William Van Cleave explains that children may choose easy words that they know how to spell. He recommends that this parent encourage his son to use the words he is thinking about even if he isn’t sure how to spell them. He also encourages parents to talk about words with children so that they can choose the best word to express their idea.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Creating safe spaces for Native kids
videos.description:
Traci Sorell's ultimate goal by writing “Indian No More” was to provide a life-saving device for young people, who are in an environment where no one understands who they are, that they are not alone. The book is a reminder that there is power in their ancestors "praying, loving, and dreaming them into being" and it is the young people's responsibility to honor their ancestors with their eyes on the future because they will be an ancestor some day.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Seeing Native children in books
videos.description:
Growing up, Traci Sorell did not come across books by Native American authors that represented Native American people. While there is much more variety in voices today, Traci believes we are no where near where we need to be. She plans to change that by mentoring and bringing other Native writers and artists as illustrators into the field.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC 

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

She met with Traci as well as Cherokee culture keepers and wisdom keepers to get a better idea of the people and landscapes that needed to be depicted in the book.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Gratitude all year long
videos.description:
According to Traci, the more attached we are to being grateful for all the things that sustain us - like the sun, the earth, and the plants - the more we will want to protect them. And perhaps being detached from nature is what is causing the climate change.  

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Seeing myself in books
videos.description:
Traci Sorell did not get to see herself in books until I she was an adult. So as an author, not only she depicts Native people in her books, but she also paints a picture of their everyday lives instead of only focusing on historical or biographical contexts. 

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Centering Native people and history
videos.description:
In her books, Traci Sorell focuses on depicting characters with all their complexities as well as a deeper look at the history of the Native peoples; important elements that she believes is missing from literary works.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Windows, mirrors, and sliding doors
videos.description:
In order to provide as authentic a representation of her characters as possible, Traci Sorell consults with many sources. Her hope us that when someone – a Cherokee person, for example – opens up a book about the Cherokee people, they feel like they can see themselves in that book; something Traci did not experience herself, as a young reader.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Writing We Are Grateful, Otsaliheliga
videos.description:
“We Are Grateful: Otsaliheliga” was the easiest book for Traci to write. While writing the book, Traci felt as if the ancestors we guiding her on this journey. 

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Writing workshops with kids
videos.description:
Participating in writing workshops for young people is one of Traci Sorell’s favorite activities. She talks about how to keep a story moving and the importance of using active verbs and rich nouns and adjectives in their writing. 

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: In service to my Cherokee community
videos.description:
From an early age, Traci realized her family was one that gave of their gifts and abilities to others and, as the first generation to graduate from college, finding ways to be of service to Native people and Native nations has been at the forefront of her mind.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Traci Sorell: Young life as a reader
videos.description:
Coming from a family of storytellers, Traci believes in the saying 'we are all made up of story' and that this was intrinsically true for her from a very early age.

Traci Sorell (Cherokee) writes for children and young adults. To see our full interview with Traci: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yLbpWW6XxbPw2ltCURHJOmC

For more author interviews visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

videos.title: Carmen Agra Deedy: How story workshops help encourage kids who don't like writing
videos.description:
Children's author Carmen Agra Deedy (Martina the Beautiful Cockroach) shares how she engages kids during writing workshops. She starts by working through the beginning-middle-end of a story out loud with the kids.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

See our video interview with Carmen Agra Deedy here: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/agra-deedy

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Books Are About Empathy
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon says that the more widely we read diverse voices, the more we understand the many points of view and experiences of people in the world. And it is from being enlightened, informed, and educated through books that we can develop a deeper sense of empathy.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Seeing Yourself in Books
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon loved reading for as long as she can remember but it wasn't until middle school when she saw the young Black girl on the cover of Mildred D. Taylor's book, Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry, that she actually saw herself represented.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: My Reading Life as a Child
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon remembers fondly her weekly trip to the library with her mother and checking out as many books as she could hold. That love of diving into a story, being immersed in a narrative, meeting new "friends" on the page definitely inspired her to want to do the same for young readers with the books she writes.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: How I Write
videos.description:
"Some writers plot and organize every scene before they write a book, others, like me, create in chaos," says Author Kekla Magoon. While creating a story, she writes in vignettes — not necessarily in order — then when she has all of her material, she moves all the pieces around and knits the story together.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Learning to Write
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon often tells young readers that one of the most important parts of being a writer is believing in your own voice and choosing the critics who want to help make your work better instead of trying to change it or tear it down. 

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Community and Activism
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon talks about how community is the foundation for all change. Often, in activism, heroes like Rosa Parks and Martin Luther King, Jr. are written about and celebrated, but it is also important to think about the 100,000s of others, young and old, who marched, protested, and wrote  ... who came together as a community in solidarity in the name of making change.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: The Season of Styx Malone: Being Black in a Small Town
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon talks about why she chose a small town in Indiana as the location for her book, The Season of Styx Malone, a summer adventure of two Black boys.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Being Extraordinary
videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon talks about how like one of her fictional characters, we can misunderstand words and that when we finally understand that misunderstanding — like "extraordinary" meaning remarkable, NOT the most ordinary — our view of ourselves can drastically change.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: Creating a Picture Book Biography of Thurgood Marshall
videos.description:
“In recognizing the humanity of our fellow beings, we pay ourselves the highest tribute,” wrote Thurgood Marshall, in one of the landmark cases he presided over as a US Supreme Court justice. The meaning behind that quote and the ways Thurgood Marshall used his life, resources, and talents in pursuit of equity for all people is the story Author Kekla Magoon tells in her first picture book, The Highest Tribute.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: She Persisted: Ruby Bridges
videos.description:
Part of Chelsea Clinton's chapter book series based on her children's book, She Persisted, Author Kekla Magoon's She Persisted: Ruby Bridges tells the story of 6-year-old Ruby Bridges, the 
the first Black student to integrate William Frantz Elementary School in New Orleans, Louisiana. Young Ruby's bravery and perseverance inspired children and adults alike to fight for equality and social justice.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Kekla Magoon: The Blue Star Graphic Novel Series
videos.description:
In Co-Authors Kekla Magoon and Cynthia Leitich Smith's Blue Star graphic novel series, two cousins, one bi-racial, one Native — based on the authors — become superheroes at their new school and in their new community all in the name of social justice.

To see our full interview with Kekla: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLxDwKxHx1yJ-0LV9lElRoV0KSUlAj591

For more author interviews, visit Reading Rockets at https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews

For interviews with middle grade and YA authors, visit https://www.adlit.org/books-and-authors/video-interviews-middle-grade-and-ya-authors

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Vaccines Do Not Cause Autism
videos.description:
The biggest myth around autism is that vaccines are the cause. Other misconceptions imply that autism is to be feared or that it stems from a personal failure or unloving parents. People also tend to think that autistic people lack empathy and that most autistic people are white, male, adolescent boys — all untrue and harmful to autistic people.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder  

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Teachers Need to Take Autistic Students' Needs Seriously
videos.description:
Autistic Journalist Eric Garcia talks about a professor he had early on in college who helped him change the trajectory of his education because he listened and helped Mr. Garcia get the supports he needed to succeed academically.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder  

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: The Need for Universally Accessible Environments in Classrooms
videos.description:
Many teachers are overworked and schools underfunded, but what matters most is creating a universally accessible environment in classrooms that help focus on the needs of autistic, disabled, and abled students alike.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder  

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Autistic People Deserve Same Opportunities as Non-Autistic Counterparts
videos.description:
Talking about universal education is important but also meaningless without first addressing the fact that autistic people are not less than. They deserve a happy and successful life and the same opportunities as anyone else.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Our Understanding of Autism Education Is Constantly Changing
videos.description:
The most important thing teachers and professors can do for their autistic students is to be open to and flexible around different learning styles and the need for various accommodations. These may change as our understanding of how autistic students learn best is expanding and deepening.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Don't Force Autistic People to Fit into a Neurotypical Mold
videos.description:
Autistic people want to learn social skills and how to interact with others but not at the expense of losing who they are. Often when neurotypical people talk about social learning they use it as a rationale to force autistic people to behave in certain ways that might not come naturally to them.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: How to Help Autistic People Feel Seen and Valued
videos.description:
Autistic Journalist Eric Garcia says it's ironic that neurotypical people accuse autistic people of having no empathy when they are criminally unempathetic to the needs and methods of communication of autistic people. 

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: How Teachers Should Help Autistic Children During a Meltdown
videos.description:
The first and most important thing a teacher should do if an autistic child is having a meltdown is to reassure them that everything will be okay and that they are safe. A meltdown is not a tantrum, rather a kid in crisis.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: A World Where We Helped Autistic People Live More Fulfilling Lives
videos.description:
Autistic Journalist Eric Garcia talks about the many layers of what a more just and equitable society for autistic people should look like.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: How the Public Understanding of Autism Has and Continues to Grow
videos.description:
In 1990, the year Autistic Journalist Eric Garcia was born — the same year the American for Disability Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act were passed — the idea that neurodiverse people were not special or damaged but deserving of the same rights and opportunities as everyone else was relatively new.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Autistic People Do Not Need to Be "Fixed"
videos.description:
No one tells people in wheelchairs that they need to learn to walk. No one tells deaf or blind people that they need to learn to hear or see. In this same vein, autistic people should be seen as fully-formed humans, not less than; fully-formed humans who want and deserve the same rights and opportunities as everyone else.

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: The Most Effective Terminology to Describe the Needs of Autistic People
videos.description:
Autistic Journalist Eric Garcia says that the terms "high functioning" and "low functioning" to describe autistic people flattens their experience. Instead, using terms to describe an autistic person with "high support needs" or "low support needs" better illustrates what autistic people need.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Lower Rates of Diagnosis for Autism in Spanish-Speaking Communities
videos.description:
While there are many misconceptions about autism throughout society, there are even more misconceptions and less information in Hispanic and other Spanish-speaking communities. More education and outreach as well as better cultural competency on behalf of psychologists, clinicians, and educators would help Spanish-speaking people get the diagnoses and accommodations needed for their autistic family members.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Additional Issues for Autistic People in Minority Groups
videos.description:
The lack of or a late diagnosis of autism can come at a serious cost in the short and long term, especially for people of color, women, and those in the LGBTQ+ community who are often misdiagnosed or overlooked.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: The Effects of How Autistic People Are Portrayed in Books and Media
videos.description:
Positive portrayals of autistic people in pop culture can shape public opinion to be more accepting, but in turn, negative, almost reductive portrayals of autistic people can lead to dismissive or dangerous ideas of autism being spread.

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: How to Help Autistic Students Who Don't Speak Succeed
videos.description:
The best way to help autistic students who can't speak succeed in school is to treat them the same way as every other student and take them seriously. Autistic students may communicate differently but they can go to school and get an education along with everyone else; they deserve the same opportunities and encouragement. 

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: What Is the Spectrum Generation and the ADA Generation?
videos.description:
Though there is still a lot of work to be done, the American for Disability Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act helped pave the way for autistic people to have a more just and equitable life. 

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Autistic People Finally Seen as the Definitive Authority on Their Own Lives
videos.description:
Autistic people were not originally included in the larger disability rights push of the 1970s, 80s, and 90s but now perceptions are changing and autistic people are more and more at the center of any public policy or decision making arena about their rights and choices.

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Journalist Eric Garcia: Advice for Parents and Teachers of Autistic Children
videos.description:
Teachers and parents are in the business of helping children become the best versions of themselves. A diagnosis of autism should not alter that one bit. 

See the full interview with Eric Garcia: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/eric-garcia

For more resources on ASD, visit Reading Rockets: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-topics/autism-spectrum-disorder 

See more Reading Rockets interviews with experts: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts

videos.title: Carmen Agra Deedy: Help your child organize their writing
videos.description:
Children's author Carmen Agra Deedy (Martina the Beautiful Cockroach) shares ideas for helping your child organize their writing.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

See our video interview with Carmen Agra Deedy here: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/agra-deedy

videos.title: Carmen Agra Deedy: My child can't think of anything to write about
videos.description:
Children's author Carmen Agra Deedy (Martina the Beautiful Cockroach) has some ideas on how to jumpstart ideas for young writers.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

See our video interview with Carmen Agra Deedy here: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/agra-deedy

videos.title: Carmen Agra Deedy: My child is upset after being diagnosed with dyslexia
videos.description:
Children's author Carmen Agra Deedy (Martina the Beautiful Cockroach) has dyslexia. Here, she shares her own personal experience understanding her dyslexia and learning to celebrate her unique strengths in how she sees the world. 

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

See our video interview with Carmen Agra Deedy here: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/agra-deedy

videos.title: Carmen Agra Deedy: The importance of revision in writing
videos.description:
Children's author Carmen Agra Deedy (Martina the Beautiful Cockroach) talks about the revision process and why that stage is so important in writing.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

See our video interview with Carmen Agra Deedy here: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/agra-deedy

videos.title: Christina Cipriano, PhD: Why Is SEL Important for Students?
videos.description:
Watch our full interview with Dr. Cipriano: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/christina-cipriano

Students who receive consistent SEL tend to have higher levels of academic achievement and fewer behavioral and social issues.

Learn more about the work of Dr. Cipriano and her colleagues at the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence (https://ycei.org/):

Managing Emotions in Times of Uncertainty & Stress 
A course designed by the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence to help school staff better manage their emotions and create supportive learning environments for students.
https://www.coursera.org/learn/managing-emotions-uncertainty-stress

RULER
RULER is an evidence-based approach to social and emotional learning (SEL) developed at the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence. RULER supports entire school communities in:
• Understanding the value of emotions
• Building the skills of emotional intelligence
• Creating and maintaining a positive school climate
• Over 3,000 schools in 27 countries have adopted the RULER approach. 
https://www.rulerapproach.org/

The State of Evidence for Social and Emotional Learning: A Contemporary Meta-Analysis of Universal School-Based SEL
This systematic review and meta-analysis provides an assessment of the current evidence for universal school-based (USB) social and emotional learning (SEL) interventions for students in kindergarten through 12th grade. 
https://osf.io/r246m 

VISIT OUR SISTER SITES

videos.description:

SEL for diverse language learners cannot simply be a translation of emotions, words, and terms because it wouldn't take into account the rich variability of cultural and linguistic nuances. To help learners from all cultures and backgrounds, the first and primary part of the SEL program approach includes full family engagement instead of considering it as an after-thought or add-on.

One of the lessons learned from the pandemic is the importance of social emotional health for everyone. If teachers don't feel safe, connected, or valued, their students won't either. videos.title: Christina Cipriano, PhD: Study Results from Pandemic on Social-Emotional Health of Educators
videos.description:
At the start of the pandemic, Dr. Cipriano and her colleagues studied 5,000 educators across the country who expressed record rates of anxiety, frustration, and feelings of being overwhelmed and undervalued. Since then, they have surveyed 25,000 more with similar results and patterns. But they have also tracked educators' increased levels of gratitude for their students and colleagues as well as for their schools and districts that are more readily recognizing and working to meet their needs.

videos.description:

Educational support professionals -- from paraprofessionals who work with high needs students to bus drivers -- play a critical role in the safety and social-emotional well-being of students and colleagues. During the pandemic, many schools cut, laid-off, or furloughed support professions, missing an important opportunity to engage them and expand their roles in the much-needed connection among students and all faculty and staff.

videos.title: Christina Cipriano, PhD: The Many Lessons Dr. Cipriano's Young Children Teach Her About SEL
videos.description:
Watch our full interview with Dr. Cipriano: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/christina-cipriano

Dr. Cipriano has four amazing children ranging from ages 9 to 21/2. Her oldest has a rare disease that is regressive and profound. When she thinks about the experience she and her family have as well as her opportunities as a parent and SEL researcher, inclusion, compassion, and empathy are what come to mind. Daily, she learns from her children who naturally show and act on inclusion, compassion, and empathy.

videos.title: Christina Cipriano, PhD: What Is Social Emotional Learning, or SEL?
videos.description:
Watch our full interview with Dr. Cipriano: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/christina-cipriano

Although it has a rich background in emotional intelligence and prevention science, SEL is a relatively new term, formalized by Casel in 1994 with the five core competencies like problem-solving and responsible decision making.

Learn more about the work of Dr. Cipriano and her colleagues at the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence (https://ycei.org/):

Managing Emotions in Times of Uncertainty & Stress 
A course designed by the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence to help school staff better manage their emotions and create supportive learning environments for students.
https://www.coursera.org/learn/managing-emotions-uncertainty-stress 

RULER
RULER is an evidence-based approach to social and emotional learning (SEL) developed at the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence. RULER supports entire school communities in:
• Understanding the value of emotions
• Building the skills of emotional intelligence
• Creating and maintaining a positive school climate
• Over 3,000 schools in 27 countries have adopted the RULER approach. 
https://www.rulerapproach.org/

The State of Evidence for Social and Emotional Learning: A Contemporary Meta-Analysis of Universal School-Based SEL
This systematic review and meta-analysis provides an assessment of the current evidence for universal school-based (USB) social and emotional learning (SEL) interventions for students in kindergarten through 12th grade. 
https://osf.io/r246m

videos.title: Reading SOS: If my concerns about my child's reading are being ignored due to bias, what can I do?
videos.description:
Literacy expert DeJunne’ Clark Jackson believes parents need to trust their gut instinct, find a strong ally as you seek answers and support, and keep detailed records of your interactions with the school. Observe how other parents are treated and seek out public records about your child's school and the district. If you're not being heard, present your case to the school, armed with facts.

videos.description:
Author Kekla Magoon talks about how publishing is finally expanding its reach to include more books from diverse points of view. By including and celebrating more and more Native, Latinx, and Black-American stories, we are giving voice to marginalized groups and building a diverse bookshelf for all.

videos.title: Reading SOS: Is it necessary to read books aloud to my deaf child?
videos.description:
Dr. Leala Holcomb, an expert in Deaf education and literacy, says that reading aloud together is a superpower in developing your child's literacy skills. You are showing your child that sharing stories, perspectives, and information are both joyful and meaningful. Read alouds also helps your child strengthen their understanding of vocabulary, grammar, and story elements. Bring the books to life as you read, and don't forget to pause and talk about the book as you go. (Presented by Dr. Leala Holcomb, interpreted by Dr. Hannah Dostal)

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: What can I do at home to set my child up for success in reading and writing?
videos.description:
Dr. Hannah Dostal, an expert in Deaf education and literacy, says it's important to surround your child with reasons to read and write. Let them see you reading and writing so they understand why it's important. Engage your child with lots of different kinds of texts, involve them in fun, everyday reading and writing tasks to build confidence, and ask your child about their writing — all of these positive experiences will help your child persist through any challenges that they might face in school. (Presented by Dr. Hannah Dostal, interpreted by Dr. Leala Holcomb)

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: How do I encourage my deaf child to do more independent reading?
videos.description:
Dr. Leala Holcomb, an expert in Deaf education and literacy, offers practical suggestions for encouraging your child to read on their own. Let your child see you reading and encourage them to choose their own books. Try reading a picture book aloud one night, and then having your child read the next night — or take turns reading the chapters in a chapter book. Both of these activities are wonderful moments of shared reading that also help your child build confidence. (Presented by Dr. Leala Holcomb, interpreted by Dr. Hannah Dostal)

videos.title: Writing SOS: How do I encourage my deaf child to write more at home?
videos.description:
Dr. Hannah Dostal, an expert in Deaf education and literacy, says that writing opens up additional opportunities for deaf children to communicate with family, friends, and their community. Writing also reinforces the connection between language (signed and spoken) and print. Help your child to see that we write for a reason, and that there are many different kinds of writing. Give your child lots of interesting and positive experiences with writing. It could be as simple as signing your name to a thank-you card or adding a note to a family calendar. And build on your child's interests — if they love comics, encourage them to create their own. (Presented by Dr. Hannah Dostal, interpreted by Dr. Leala Holcomb)

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: How do I, as a hearing parent, read aloud with my deaf child?
videos.description:
Dr. Leala Holcomb, an expert in Deaf education and literacy, says that all children — hearing and deaf — need the experience of being read to by a caring adult. Dr. Holcomb offers lots of tips for making the experience fun and full of learning, including these: use your most expressive reading voice, bring your child's attention to key English words, explain the differences between similar English words, talk about English words that have more than one meaning, point out changes in font size and punctuation and talk about what it means, and switch back and forth between English and ASL. And don't worry if you are still learning to sign — your enthusiasm will be contagious! (Presented by Dr. Leala Holcomb, interpreted by Dr. Hannah Dostal)

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.description:

In all of her research, she focuses on how that information can help her develop the story, characters, and the heart of it all.

videos.description:
As an adult, Author Paula Yoo found a box of self-portraits she had drawn when she was little. The early ones look like her with dark hair and eyes, but the ones she drew after moving back to the US from Korea, where didn't feel she fit in either, portray her with blond hair and blue eyes. Now, as a writer, she wants kids like her to see themselves represented in books, and hopes that with more diverse books in the world, no kid will need to draw themselves to look like everyone else.

videos.description:
The moment Author Paula Yoo finished E. B. White's Charlotte's Web when she was in 1st grade, she knew she had to be a writer. From there, she made hundreds of little stapled books complete with titles, chapters, and an author picture and bio. And she sent her first novel, 75 pages, when in 2nd grade, to Harper and Row (now Harper Collins). Although they rejected it, she persisted, and three decades later, Harper Collins published her first novel, Good Enough.

See our full interview with Paula Yoo: https://www.readingrockets.org/books/interviews/yoo

videos.title: Writing SOS: What’s the most important writing skill to encourage in my child?
videos.description:
Ideas, organization, and clarifying, rich details are all important in writing, but literacy specialist Kyley Pulphus emphasizes voice when working with young writers. She encourages kids to write in their own unique voice, and shares “mentor texts” by writers from different backgrounds — authors like Jason Reynolds. Kyley talks about how writers use slang and dialect or mix languages to give their writing a natural, authentic voice.

This video is part of our special series, Writing SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about writing and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/writing-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Reading SOS: What literacy skills indicate my kindergartener is on track for reading?
videos.description:
Early literacy expert Bernadette Pilar Zermeño says that parents can watch for and support these pre-reading skills: interest in learning about and using new words, lots of talking (and expressing increasingly complex ideas through oral language), rhyming and playing with word sounds, letter awareness, and understanding how books work.

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook: What Elementary Teachers Should Know About Autistic Kids
videos.description:
Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook says that most autistic girls feel as if they were not given the social rule book for life, which makes playing with peers, understanding others' motivation, and expressing themselves all but impossible. But with knowledge and understanding, teachers can help their students better express themselves and fit in, which for an autistic girl can be life-changing, life-saving.

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook on Helping Autistic Kids Run with Their Interests
videos.description:
As an autistic person, parent, and former teacher, Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook knows the power of helping — allowing — kids to tap into their special interests. In fact, she says, there is no better way for teachers and parents to coax an autistic student out of their shell and help them develop their sense of self than by using that special interest as a bridge to better developing social skills, academic skills, etc.

See our full interview with Jennifer Cook here: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/jennifer-cook

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook on the Refuge of Books
videos.description:
Growing up, Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook says books were a literally her best friends — a refuge from the world of directions, peers, and social skills that were so hard to navigate. The Little House on the Prairie and Anne of Green Gables books, in particular, transported Ms. Cook to a place and time where she could be an expert and "not mess up."

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook on Learning to Be One's Authentic Self
videos.description:
Autistic girls are often expert as camouflaging or masking their challenges, especially before they are diagnosed or "identified." Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook says that once diagnosed, it can be a beautiful thing when family and friends welcome and celebrate you for all your differences, allowing your authentic self to surface, instead of saying, "for your own good, you must change ..."

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook: What Her Tiny Semi-Colon Tattoo Means
videos.description:
Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook has a tiny tattoo of a semi-colon on the inside of her left wrist. Sure, she has an odd love of punctuation but what the tattoo symbolizes is the fact that no matter how hard things are going, her story is not over ... there is more to come. "You never know what's on the next page, no matter what has come before that, but the best part is that you get to be the author," she says.

See our full interview with Jennifer Cook here: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/jennifer-cook

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook: What Does It Mean to Be Autistic?
videos.description:
For Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook, being asked what it means to be autistic is like being asked "what it means to be me." The hardest part, she says, is "feeling so smart but so stupid at the same time." That said, she tries to think of herself as different ... so smart "and" anything she wants to be instead of so smart "but" ...

See our full interview with Jennifer Cook here: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/jennifer-cook

videos.title: Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook on What Autistic Girls Should Not Be Told
videos.description:
Author and Autism Advocate Jennifer Cook remembers as a little girl, diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome, being told she was "too smart for her own good and invariably overly sensitive." For her, her "otherwise unrelated constellation of symptoms" from being autistic felt like looking at the stars from the moon instead of from the earth; of course, they were going to look totally different ... but everyone wanted her to see and feel and experience life as if from the "normal" view.

See our full interview with Jennifer Cook here: https://www.readingrockets.org/teaching/experts/jennifer-cook

videos.title: Reading SOS: Can parents help a third grader with comprehension?
videos.description:
A parent says that her son can read a story but can't have a conversation about it. Third grade teacher Chelsey Short shares simple ideas to help your child understand what they read — break down the story into smaller pieces, give a reason or purpose for reading, and encourage your child to look back in the text for answers. She also has some suggestions for making this practice more fun!

This video is part of our special series, Reading SOS, where parents ask the experts their questions about reading and how to support their kids at home. See the full series here: https://www.readingrockets.org/reading-sos-with-experts

videos.title: Author Christina Soontornvat: Thai Culture Is Essential in the Narrative of "All Thirteen"
videos.description:
When writing her book,  "All Thirteen: The Incredible Cave Rescue of the Thai Boys' Soccer Team,"  Author Christina Soontornvat recalls watching the American media coverage of the story and how the media misunderstood and was often disrespectful of Thai culture. So, it was important to her that readers of the book learn some of the nuances of Thai culture so as to better understand how the boys, their families, and the community acted during that 18-day vigil and ultimate rescue.

videos.title: Melissa Stewart: Vocabulary Learning Through Children’s Books
videos.description:
Melissa says that it’s important to think carefully about vocabulary when you’re writing a children’s book. A sprinkling of large words can add a lot to the text, especially when they are specific, precise words that describe a certain phenomenon or animal behavior. You don't want so many large words that children really have trouble following the text or they feel overwhelmed.

videos.title: Melissa Stewart: Teaching Kids the Craft of Writing Nonfiction
videos.description:
Melissa talks about the importance of assimilating all of your research, in order to make your own personal meaning. In her writing workshops, Melissa has students ask these questions about their topic: What is it that resonates with you? What about this person is specifically exciting to you? What are you dying to share with other people? When you focus in on that, your writing will become more engaging.

videos.title: Ebony Holliday, PhD on the Importance of Early Intervention for Young Students with Autism
videos.description:
Ebony Holliday, PhD, assistant director of Community Programs at Kennedy Krieger Institute’s Center for Autism Services, Science and Innovation (CASSI), explains that the earlier a child is diagnosed with autism and receives interventions, the better their outcome in the future. "We know about neuroplasticity ... we know that we are wired to learn and grow so that when kids are very young, we can work to deliver enriching interventions that focus on their developmental delays or differences," she says.

VISIT OUR SISTER SITES

videos.title: Sentence Unpacking in 4th Grade
videos.description:
In this 4th grade lesson, students are using the sentence unpacking strategy to deconstruct a sentence from their social studies text. See the related blog post from the teacher, Mr. Lawton: Unpacking Sentences, Packing in Learning. https://discussionsforlearningpilotinousd.blogspot.com/2018/02/unpacking-sentences-packing-in-learning.html
